Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 53112-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2019 
 
 
 
 
Supporting Internationalization of Small and 
Medium-Sized Enterprises: Linking India and the 
Greater Mekong Subregion 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  FDI  –  foreign direct investment 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  GVC  –  global value chain 
  IBA  –  international business accelerator 
  IT  –  information technology 
  SDCC  –  Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
  SDTC-RCI  –  Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group 
  SME  –  small and medium-sized enterprise 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-Presidents  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  Woochong Um, Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department (SDCC) 
Director  Arjun Goswami, Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic 
Group, SDCC 
   
Team leaders  Ashish Narain, Principal Economist (Regional Cooperation), SDCC 
Sherwin Pu, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Team member  Dominic Mellor, Senior Investment Specialist, PSOD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 19062019081541704270 Generated Date: 30-Oct-2019 14:21:15 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will operationalize initiatives that 
catalyze trade and cross-border investment (internationalization) by small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs) between India and countries in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), 
contributing to enhanced regional integration and higher and more inclusive growth in both the 
GMS and South Asian regions.1 It will focus on Cambodia, Thailand, and Viet Nam among 
countries in the GMS. The TA builds on recommendations of analytical studies that looked at the 
potential for and challenges of connecting SMEs across Cambodia, India, and Thailand.2 
 
2.  The TA will seek to do this by (i) establishing and/or partnering with business accelerators 
in  India  and  Thailand  (to  cover  the  GMS)  to  identify  SMEs  with  the  potential  for 
internationalization;3 and providing the identified SMEs with a composite package, including 
information on opportunities, industry expertise, mentoring, and guidance on market entry issues 
to assist their internationalization; (ii) supporting linkages between business associations and/or 
organizations promoting SME internationalization; and (iii) supporting linkages between business 
accelerators and financial intermediaries. 
 
3.  The TA is included in the management approved 2019 results-based work plan of the 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC) of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB). It is aligned closely with ADB’s Strategy 2030 that emphasizes fostering regional 
cooperation  and  integration  among  ADB’s  developing  member  countries (DMCs).4 The  TA 
supports the expansion of global and regional trade and investment opportunities.5 It is also in 
agreement with ongoing initiatives by the governments in Cambodia, India, Thailand, and Viet 
Nam that support greater integration and development of SMEs. The first prerequisites for the 
internationalization of SMEs is access to quality infrastructure, a good enabling environment, and 
helping SMEs to grow and become competitive. Therefore, this TA will complement a proposed 
development program for SMEs in India,6 and similar programs aimed at SMEs in other target 
countries. Although the TA will be implemented over 2 years, it will be designed to attract financing 
from other public and private sources to allow activities to be sustained over the medium term. 
The TA will also impact poverty because it will support raising growth and productivity in SMEs 
that generate employment especially for the poor and low-skilled. The TA will also impact gender 
equality because it will make a special effort to support SMEs led and/or owned by women through 
the accelerator program. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Opportunities. India has been trying to promote economic cooperation and cultural ties 
and develop strategic relationships with countries in Asia and the Pacific through its Act East 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the website of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on 
30 October 2019. 
2  ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance for Facilitating Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Foreign Direct Investment 
Flows: An ASEAN+6 Case Study. Manila. Under the TA, country reports were produced for Cambodia, India, and 
Thailand. Viet Nam was studied but no formal country report was produced. 
3  A business accelerator is a program that gives developing companies access to mentorship, investors, and other 
support that help them grow their businesses. 
4 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
5 ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7: Fostering Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2019–
2024. Manila.  
6  At the request of the Government of India, ADB is developing a support program based on the concept of value 
chain-based cluster development. This will likely include infrastructure interventions and strengthening of institutional 
and regulatory frameworks. This is targeted for approval in 2020.

2 
Policy.7 The GMS offers particular potential for stronger economic relations, as it is close to India 
and has historical and cultural connections. Trade and investment between India and the GMS 
are low, but there are large potential gains to both from integration, in terms of boosting growth, 
employment, and resilience. Closer integration with GMS countries offers opportunities for India 
to diversify its exports, and better link with the global value chains (GVCs) centered in East Asia. 
For GMS countries, India offers a large and growing market, and could be a source of inward 
foreign direct investment. Increased integration with India is an important part of the strategies of 
GMS countries as well.8 
 
5.  SMEs will need to be an integral part of any strategy to link India and the GMS. The main 
attraction for Indian firms looking to enter the GMS is access to GVCs, which is likely to be a big 
draw for SMEs looking to internationalize.9 Similarly, the large market in India is a big draw for 
SMEs in Thailand.10 Participation of SMEs can help deepen integration and make benefits more 
inclusive by creating more and better jobs. International experience shows that enhancing 
involvement with global markets is key to strengthening the competitiveness of SMEs and their 
contribution to economic development, job creation, and social well-being. 
 
6.  The study and follow-up demand. In 2017, the Government of India requested ADB to 
conduct a study on how to promote trade and investment through SMEs between India and the 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), in particular Cambodia, Thailand, and Viet Nam 
(footnote 2). In response, in 2018 ADB’s Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group 
(SDTC-RCI) produced country reports on Cambodia, India, and Thailand to understand the push-
and-pull factors that lead SMEs to internationalize; the constraints SMEs in the region face in 
internationalizing; and the support they need to undertake this successfully. The reports found 
that there is significant scope for SMEs to become more integrated across India and the GMS. A 
reasonably  large  number  of  SMEs  in  all  economies  covered  in  this  TA  are  already 
internationalized,  and  regularly  conduct  overseas  business,  either  in  the  form  of  trade  or 
investment. Further, a significant number of SMEs show the potential to be internationalized.11 
There are many opportunities for Indian SMEs to conduct business in the GMS countries involving 
apparel, autoparts, information technology (IT) and IT-enabled services, pharmaceuticals, and 
leather. There is also considerable interest in the GMS to conduct business in India involving 
autoparts, agro-processing, IT and IT-enabled services, logistics, and wellness; some areas of 
focus (e.g., autoparts and apparel) are characterized by the presence of GVCs. 
 
7.  An agreement has been secured from the DMC governments covered in this TA on 
actioning report recommendations. In addition, the team for this TA has held consultations with 
private sector stakeholders, who expressed a strong need to move forward with a project that 
gives momentum to nascent but growing business-to-business contact between India and the 
GMS countries. 
 
8.  Challenges. The first challenge is to vitalize SMEs and enhance their competitiveness 
through infrastructure development, adequate institutional and regulatory support, and access to 
 
7  The objective of the policy is to promote economic cooperation and cultural ties and develop strategic relationship 
with countries in the Asia and Pacific region through trade, culture, people-to-people contacts, and physical 
infrastructure. Government of India, Ministry of External Affairs, Press Information Bureau. Act East Policy.  
8  Such as Thailand’s “Look West” policy and Cambodia Industrial Development Policy, which promotes inward FDI. 
9  ADB. Supporting Internationalization of India’s Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises: Linking India and ASEAN’s 
Mekong Region. Unpublished. 
10 ADB. Internationalizing Thailand’s Micro-Small-And Medium Sized Enterprises: The Case of India. Unpublished. 
11  Elaborated in the Supplementary Document on Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises in India and the Greater 
Mekong Subregion (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

3 
finance. This requires interventions by governments in support of SME development. Some 
growth-oriented SMEs may then seek to internationalize as part of their growth strategy.12 This 
may require additional support from private sector stakeholders. Entering a foreign market can be 
expensive,  time-consuming,  and  risky,  while  SMEs  typically  have  limited  resources.  Not 
surprisingly, SMEs tend to be hesitant globalizers, even when the benefits are significant, and for 
this  reason  require  support.  To  understand  the  main  challenges  that  SMEs  face  in 
internationalizing, the RCI TG reports presented the results of a survey of about 1,200 SMEs and 
face-to-face  interviews  with  key  informants.13  The  reports  identified  the  following  primary 
problems (footnotes 9 and 10): 
(i)  Information  and  capacity  constraints  among  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises. The survey and interviews reveal a significant gap in information 
among SMEs in both India and the GMS. Most SMEs from one region, either India 
or the GMS, do not know what to expect in the other region or are misinformed of 
prospects.  There  are  few  sources  to  fill  this  gap:  established  contacts  with 
suppliers and business partners, or peers who are trading across India and the 
GMS. SMEs also are not fully aware of trade agreements, how to take advantage 
of these, or of e-commerce opportunities. Further, trade or investment promotion 
agencies from the destination country typically do not actively reach out to SMEs. 
The lack of prior exposure to the other region also means that SMEs require 
guidance and assistance when venturing abroad. There is a need to demonstrate 
early  successes  and  risk  mitigation  through  internationalization  of  SMEs  to 
persuade other SMEs to purse internationalization. 
(ii)  Weak  coordination  among  organizations  supporting  small  and medium-
sized  enterprises  moving  across  borders. Most  SMEs  wish to  enter  new 
markets through joint ventures with local businesses. Finding a good business 
partner was reported as a critical factor for successful entry. However, there are 
few  links  between  destination  and  origin  country  business  associations  and 
organizations that support SMEs, resulting in limited information sharing and 
coordination,  which  renders  making  effective  contacts  between  SMEs  and 
conducting follow-up difficult. 
(iii)  Underdeveloped  support  ecosystems  for  internationalizing  small  and 
medium-sized  enterprises.  High-potential  SMEs  need  access  to  support 
networks that combine acceleration and financing. While there are specialized 
institutions offering financing for internationalizing SMEs (export-import banks and 
venture capital funds), these are not well connected with accelerators that can 
create a pipeline of internationalizing SMEs with financeable business plans. In the 
absence of this link, the results of such financing facilities have been mixed. Global 
evidence suggests that deepening relationships, promoting collaboration, and 
improving information flows between stakeholders produce large benefits.14 
 
 
12 For example, Cranes Software International from India invested in Singapore to support its relationship with Texas 
Instruments and has used this as a base to serve many countries in ASEAN. Similarly, Indian companies—such as 
Frost International; Teledata Informatic (IT); Commeasure (hospitality); Grofers (grocery delivery); and AdNear 
(mobile advertising network)—have started operations in ASEAN to access international markets, supplement export 
activities, or expand their product portfolio. 
13 Explained in Supplementary Document 3-Key Capacity-Building Needs of Internationalizing Small and Medium-
Sized Enterprises (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
14 While much has been done through trade finance programs with banks, the less benign global environment on cross-
border trade and investment requires additional regional efforts. Instead of producing credit lines for such agencies, 
a more SME portfolio-intensive approach is likely to support financing objectives for SMEs more meaningfully.

4 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: movement of internationalized SMEs between 
India and the GMS increased.15 The TA will have the following outcome: internationalization of 
SMEs supported.16 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1:  International business accelerators established. The TA will run twin 
international business accelerators (IBAs) in Thailand and India to offer SMEs support services 
they need, that will (i) identify potential SMEs willing and potentially able to move; (ii) identify their 
capacity-building needs and provide suitable training, including on strengthening management, 
standards, rules of origin, and the use of e-commerce; (iii) help SMEs create and implement a 
financeable business plan and link the plan to potential sources of finance; (iv) connect SMEs 
with professional networks in the destination that can mentor them through issues of market entry; 
(v) create a roster of certified business service providers at the destination (lawyers, accountants, 
and business consultants); and (vi) track SMEs graduating from the program, and report on 
achievements. The IBAs model will (i) act on a “twin basis” by catering to GMS companies and 
providing  them  the  services  and  facilities  they  need  to  quickly,  conveniently,  reliably,  and 
affordably launch initial operations in a foreign country (i.e., India) as well as help Indian SMEs in 
setting up in the GMS; (ii) specifically target India–GMS internationalization;17 (iii) make a special 
effort to target SMEs led and/or owned by women through support for the accelerator program;18 
and (iv) provide a special focus on ensuring sustainability of the accelerator beyond the TA. 
Cambodia and Viet Nam are expected to benefit mainly through increased trade and inward 
foreign direct investment from India, although the IBA will also reach out to SMEs in Cambodia 
and Viet Nam that may be interested in the Indian market. The IBAs will proactively reach out to 
industries prioritized by the respective governments and identified as having potential but will rely 
on business associations to identify potential SMEs. The IBAs will subsequently also reach out to 
other sources, including SMEs benefiting from government programs. 
 
11.  Output 2: Cooperation between India and the Greater Mekong Subregion countries’ 
business  associations  and/or  organizations  supporting  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises facilitated. The TA will organize at least two business match-making events jointly 
with GMS and Indian business associations and/or organizations supporting SMEs. These events 
will (i) identify SMEs interested in entering the accelerator program and finding potential business 
partners in the destination country; (ii) connect SMEs in the accelerator program with potential 
business partners in the destination country; (iii) reach out to chambers of commerce and 
business associations for women-owned businesses; (iv) be used to improve information flows, 
 
15 Movement refers to increased activity, either in the form of increased exports, receiving inward foreign direct 
investment (FDI), or making outward FDI. It includes the possibility of indirect internationalization. For example, 
Indian SMEs may choose to enter GMS markets indirectly through other destinations, such as Singapore or Hong 
Kong, China. 
16 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
17 The IBA model has emerged as a common mechanism to support entrepreneurial expansion, including in the target 
DMCs. However existing accelerators do not target India–GMS internationalization, which is the focus of this TA. 
18 The TA will coordinate with and benefit from cross-learning from ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance for Promoting 
Transformative Gender Equality Agenda in Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

5 
including use of emerging technologies in streamlining and simplifying cross-border regulations,19 
and coordination between the associations on a sustained basis; and (v) identify policy reforms 
needed to facilitate internationalization of SMEs and discuss these with government. To achieve 
sustained results beyond events, (i) IBAs will further support SMEs in following through on the 
initial contacts made during these events and (ii) the TA will support the establishment of an online 
partnering website to be maintained by the associations on a permanent basis. 
 
12.  Output 3: Coordination between financial intermediaries and accelerators of small 
and medium-sized enterprises strengthened. The TA will organize two workshops that will 
bring together SMEs from the IBA program and specialized financial institutions such as export–
import banks and venture funds to generate financing for the SMEs being supported by the IBA. 
This can help make the IBA sustainable (e.g., by charging a success fee), and help establish a 
partnership to build the foundations for a more comprehensive strategy of regional trade and 
investment promotion backed by financial intermediaries focusing on the special needs of SMEs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
United Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation 
and Integration Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. 
 
14.  Eligible activities for financing include the cost of expert services and related facilities 
required for the TA or related operational activities (including staff training and development for 
eligible DMCs) to be carried out by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented from December 2019 to December 2021. ADB will be the 
executing agency. ADB’s SDTC-RCI will be responsible for administering the TA, with TA 
implementation oversight co-led by ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department’s Business 
Development Team. In its implementation, a one-ADB approach will be followed by working 
closely with ADB’s South Asia Department and Southeast Asia Department to leverage their 
government relations, industry knowledge, and sector networks. The TA will leverage and support 
a proposed development program for SMEs requested by the Government of India.20 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  November 2019–November 2021 
Executing agency  SDTC-RCI, SDCC, ADB 
Implementing agencies  SDTC-RCI, SDCC, ADB 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
 
19 For example, ADB’s SDCC is conducting a study using smart contracts and machine-readable legislation to assist 
governments and SMEs to standardize procedures across borders and make customs-related transactions traceable 
and accountable. 
20  Explained in Diagram of One-ADB Support for Development of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises in India 
(accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
17.  Consulting services. One consulting firm will be engaged through the fixed budget 
selection method for a total of about 24 person-months to deliver output 1. The firm will be an 
experienced implementor with a track record in developing and operating sustainable business 
development service programs, preferably in developing countries. Another consulting firm will be 
engaged through the fixed budget selection method for a total of about 24 person-months to 
deliver output 2. The firm will be a reputed business association or a consortium with well-
developed business networks, including in the sectors of interest identified above. In addition, the 
TA will require 12 person-months of individual international and 20 person-months of individual 
national consulting services to provide technical and administrative support. Resource persons 
will serve as coordinators and/or facilitators for meetings. ADB will engage the consultants 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.21 
 
18.  Social media and websites. ADB will support the establishment and maintenance of the 
website (Output 2) by partner business associations during the period of the TA. The TA will work 
with the business associations and the IBA to see how this will be sustained beyond the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$3,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the United Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade 
and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility 
for Supporting Internationalization of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises: Linking India and the 
Greater Mekong Subregion, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
 
21 Output-based or lump sum contracts will be considered for consulting services, where appropriate, with the 
concurrence of ADB’s Procurement, Portfolio and Financial Management Department. Terms of reference for 
consultants are accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3.

curriculum (Q2 2020).

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  FDI  –  foreign direct investment 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  GVC  –  global value chain 
  IBA  –  international business accelerator 
  IT  –  information technology
